Personal Statement

I am Rada Forkova. I negotiate peace with forks.

Age 11: school cafeteria, fish sticks, one fork flipped and launched peas into my left eye. Since then, I have dedicated my adult life to utensil de-escalation.

Tiny Aggressive Rakes is a lifestyle company, a risk protocol, and frankly a support group for people who know a fork is never just a fork. It is four little ultimatums.

What your first 30 days look like

  1. Week 1: identify your household's top three "sudden fork events."
  2. Week 2: replace one aggressive utensil with a neutral spoon.
  3. Week 3: rehearse calm phrase: "Let us mash, not jab."
Newsroom & Personnel

Updates from headquarters (former dental office, Unit B)

Press release: We reject the term "anti-fork"

Tiny Aggressive Rakes confirms it is pro-consent utensil usage. We believe forks can change with coaching, boundaries, and proper tine orientation.

Issued Jan 8 at 6:14 AM after an incident involving shrimp cocktail.

Field note #204: Airport food courts

Regression spike detected near Gate C17. Passengers under stress are defaulting to forks for soft noodles. We deployed two volunteer spoon ambassadors and one laminated calm sign.

Outcome: peaceful ramen in 23 minutes.

FAQ

Questions I hear at every pop-up kiosk

Are you legally allowed to call forks "tiny aggressive rakes"?

Yes. Our legal counsel says it's "descriptive language with emotional accuracy."

I love forks. Can I still join?

Absolutely. We are a rehabilitation-first culture. Bring your fork. We begin with listening.

Do you do weddings?

Yes. We provide aisle-side spoon baskets and discreet intervention if an uncle starts gesturing with a salad fork.

What is your return policy?

30 days. If your household achieved complete utensil harmony, keep the whistle. You've earned it.

Request a table audit

Tell me where tension spikes: breakfast, potlucks, or your mother's lasagna night.

Received. I will arrive with a clipboard and no judgment.
